head.title: TVR's Long and Winding Road Leads (for Now) to Florida

hedline.hl1: TVR's Long and Winding Road Leads (for Now) to Florida
hedline.hl2: TVR’s Long and Winding Road Leads (for Now) to Florida

block.p: LIKE the mythical Monty Python castle built on a swamp, which sank three times only to be rebuilt three times, one of Britain's last sports car makers has risen again after several near-death experiences and ownership changes.

One of Britain’s last sports car makers has risen again after several near-death experiences and ownership changes.

LIKE the mythical Monty Python castle built on a swamp, which sank three times only to be rebuilt three times, one of Britain's last sports car makers has risen again after several near-death experiences and ownership changes.

The company, TVR, would fit neatly in the comedic Python world, where cheese shops have no cheese to sell and hyper-litigious businessmen accidentally sue themselves. Consider its recent history: its third owner since 1981 was a 20-something Russian who actually owned the company twice in three years.
The latest owners are two Florida men, Adam Burdette and Jean-Michel Santacreu, who took control of TVR in February.

Although neither man has run an auto company -- Mr. Burdette had been a car importer and Mr. Santacreu a hotel consultant -- they have already lined up suppliers and made plans to sell the cars in the United States beginning in 2008. Their flagship model is an evil-looking 380-horsepower car that the previous owner had introduced.

That owner, Nikolai Smolenski, 26, a Russian banker who once ran his father's banking group, had also never managed a car company. He bought TVR in July 2004, but lost control in 2006 to bankruptcy administrators -- who sold it back to him in February. Less than a week later, he sold the company to Mr. Burdette and Mr. Santacreu.

Like its corporate history, TVR's models were always a little odd, but they were often exciting hand-built sports cars. The company, which was based in Blackpool, England, took its name from three letters in the first name of its founder, Trevor Wilkinson.

The first TVR was built in 1947. A small number of club racing specials came in the next decade, but production did not really begin until the late 1950s when TVR hit on this formula: a light fiberglass body mounted on an even lighter tubular space frame.

Early TVRs were sold in two forms, as finished cars and as kits. But even the factory-built cars resembled kit cars, with fit and finish reminiscent of a high school shop project. It scarcely mattered because most early TVRs became racecars anyway.

The most exciting early TVR was created by Jack Griffith, a Long Island car dealer. Having seen what Carroll Shelby did with the Cobra, he put a Ford small-block V-8 into the TVR Grantura. At just 1,850 pounds and with up to 271 horsepower, the car was sensationally fast.

Unfortunately, with a wheelbase of just 85.5 inches and suspension, brakes and rear end scarcely changed from the four-cylinder car, the Griffith 200 was badly balanced and hard to control. To make matters worse, the cars overheated and the tremendous torque of their engines often broke axles, causing wheels to fly off. Even with all four wheels attached, Griffiths were nearly uncontrollable.

In 1965, Martin Lilley, who was 23 at the time, bought TVR after a dock strike in New York nearly bankrupted the company. Mr. Lilley discontinued the Griffith, but not before trying to tame the car, renaming the new version the Tuscan V-8. Road & Track magazine still called the car ''a ferret with an oversupply of Y chromosomes.''
Mr. Lilley's 16-year stewardship of TVR was quite positive. In 1972, he introduced what would become the most popular model up to then, the 2500M.

Along with Mr. Lilley, Gerry Sagerman, the United States distributor from 1966 to 1980, set up a network of more than 30 dealers and was selling around 75 percent of TVR's total production. Sales usually totaled 500 to 600 cars a year, mainly the 2500M.

The American effort was hindered, Mr. Sagerman said, because the factory could not make enough cars to meet demand and the company was unable to get emission certification in California, which should have been TVR's largest American market.
Mr. Sagerman showed a new convertible model, the 3000S, at the 1978 Los Angeles Auto Show, but the reaction scared him.
''People were literally pushing money in my face trying to buy the cars,'' he said in an interview last month. ''I knew that there was no way we could satisfy even a fraction of the demand.''

As a small-volume manufacturer, TVR had to rely on larger companies for major components. Steering columns, engines and transmissions for the 2500M came from the popular Triumph TR6 sports car. But it is the origin of the minor assemblies that confound restorers and owners. Factory support for these early cars is nonexistent, and the company did not leave a Rosetta Stone explaining where all the parts came from.

Members of TVR owners clubs have tried to discover the origin of the 2500M's parts. And while members now know that the door hinges are from a Ford Anglia and the hood latches from something called a Hillman Imp, they don't know the origin of the radiator overflow bottle. But it's all part of the fun of being part collector-car owner and part automotive archaeologist.

Continually at the mercy of other manufacturers, TVR had to quickly substitute a Ford 3-liter V-6 in its next models, the Taimar and the 3000S, after the engine it had planned to use, a 2.5-liter in-line 6 from the Triumph TR6, became unavailable. (Triumph discontinued that car.)

Along with the Taimar Turbo, the pretty 3000S roadster is also quite collectible. Essentially a convertible Taimar, the 3000S had no rollup windows, instead using removable side curtains like the MGA and other vintage British sports cars.

By the end of the 1970s, inflation and exchange rates were pushing TVRs further upmarket, and Mr. Sagerman ended his association with TVR. Oliver Winterbottom, a former Lotus engineer, was brought in to work on what became the Tasmin, a wedge-shaped two-seat coupe and convertible.

The development of the Tasmin, which later became the 280i, dragged on, and by the time TVR introduced the car, the wedge styling fad was just about over and inflation had pushed the 280i into competition with cars that it could not match in either quality or performance. Consequently, the wedge cars, as the 280i series became known, were hard to sell at anywhere near their sticker price of about $25,000.

Marshall Moore, president of the TVR Car Club of North America, remembered a Toyota-TVR dealership in Washington that had many unsold TVRs. ''It was truly sad to see the little cars gathering dust or even cannibalized for spares when the factory stopped supporting them,'' he said.
In 1987, TVR pulled out of the American market, awash in unsold cars and unfulfilled warranty claims. Peter Wheeler, a chemical engineer who bought the company in 1981, vowed never to return.

Although the 280i was a pleasant sports car with great handling, prices have hardly appreciated. Hayes Harris, a classic car dealer and TVR expert in Vero Beach, Fla., said good examples were available for $10,000 to $12,000.

At a meeting in Florida in March, the new owners met with prospective American dealers. Marian Posdamer, a company spokeswoman, said that Mr. Santacreu told the dealers that the company planned to assemble a network among established exotic-car dealers in major markets. The new owners brought to the meeting a Sagaris, the last model introduced in the Smolenski era and the flagship of the revived company, wrapped in an American flag to underscore their intentions.

The Sagaris will never be mistaken for a cuddly Miata. It has a demonic face with hornlike curved headlights. It looks just right for a $100,000 sports car that the company says is capable of 0-60 acceleration in 3.7 seconds. TVR also plans to sell another high-performance two-seater, the Tuscan.

Through Ms. Posdamer, Mr. Santacreu said TVR planned to use several companies as suppliers. He said I. M. Kelly Automotive, a British company that has worked on Aston Martins, Jaguars and Land Rovers, would supply interiors. Ricardo will assemble the engines, Hi Tech Automotive of South Africa will produce the bodies and chassis and the coachbuilder Bertone of Italy will do the final assembly work.
If the chat rooms and the blogosphere are any indication, some sports car buffs are eager to buy a TVR that performs like a new Viper or Corvette but looks even meaner.
